column1: Pomezia (Italian pronunciation: [poˈmɛttsja]) is a municipality (comune) in the Metropolitan City of Rome
column3: central Italy. In 2009 it had a population of about 60

column1: The town was built entirely new near the location of ancient Lavinium on land resulting from the final reclamation of the Pontine Marshes under Benito Mussolini
column2: being inaugurated on 29 October 1939. Its new population was extracted from the poor peasants of Romagna
column3: Veneto and Friuli. Peace did not last long. After being occupied by the forces of the Third Reich
column4: Pomezia was heavily bombed during the Battle of Anzio in World War II. After the end of the war
column5: Pomezia developed as a strong industrial center
column6: especially in the medical and pharmaceutical sectors
column7: as well as a recreational center. It is also home to the production plant of Italian food company Colavita.

column1: Pratica di Mare is the "frazione" of Pomezia where the ruins of the ancient port of Lavinium are located
column2: now 6 kilometres (4 mi) from the Tyrrhenian Sea. The ancient community was on some hilly ground at the mouth of a stream. Currently the flat alluvial sediment between the hill and the beach is occupied by Pratica di Mare Air Force Base
column3: a facility of the Aeronautica Militare that also finds great utility as a secure airport and a location for air shows and races.

column1: The name of Pomezia comes from the Latin city of Suessa Pometia
column2: although it is unknown where Pometia was located.
